Performance comparison with Amazon, Google, and Microsoft tools in OCR, layout, and table detection raises concerns over RAGFlow's completely open-source status due to its dependence on closed-source components.

title: The Legacy of Daniel: A 3,400-Year Journey
originBody: The Tale of Daniel Contact via Email Open Github account in new tab Posted on Apr 01, 2024 Itâ€™s April Cools! Itâ€™s like April Fools, except instead of cringe comedy you make genuine content thatâ€™s different what you usually do. For example, last year I talked about the strangest markets on the internet. This year I went down a different rabbit hole. Daniel has been a top 5 baby name twice since 2000. There are over 1.5 million Daniels in the United States (and almost 100,000 last-name Danielses). There are who knows how many Dans, Dannies, and Daniellas out there. â€œDanielâ€ is, by any way you slice it, a very modern name. It may be the oldest attested name in common use. Last year was Chicagoâ€™s last Newberry Library book sale. Part of my haul was several collections of ancient literature: Iâ€™m interested in ancient history, which shouldnâ€™t be a surprise to anybody who reads this blog. And I love how their literature reflects the modern human experience. Take this lament carved in a pyramid from the Egyptian Middle Kingdom: I have heard the words of Imohotep and Hardedef \ Whose sayings are recited whole. \ What of their places? Their walls have crumbled, \ Their places are gone, \ As though they had never been! (pg 196) This anonymous poet, writing 4500 years ago, shares our fears about losing our past and of our memories being forgotten. Beautiful. But I found something far more relevant in the Mesopotamian literature. Straightway Daniel the Raphaman â€¦ gives oblations to the gods to eat (pg 118) Daniel the Raphaman DANIEL The story comes from the Tale of Aqhat, pulled out of the ruins of a forgotten city, estimated to approximately 1350 BCE. Thatâ€™s a hundred years older than the oldest known Chinese writing, one thousand years older than the book of Daniel, and thirty-four hundred years before today. I needed to know if this was the same name, transmitted across cultures, stretching 3400 years of unbroken â€œDanielsâ€ to our modern day. Is this where â€œDanielâ€ comes from, or is just a strange coincidence? A historian of the modern world has to learn how to sip from a firehose of evidence, while the historian of the ancient world must learn how to find water in the desert. â€” Bret Devereaux Iâ€™ve done some historical work before, but all of it was in software, a â€œhistory of the modern worldâ€. I decided to try anyway. This is what Iâ€™ve put together from reading books and trawling JSTOR.1 This is the tale of Daniel. Ugarit Obviously, finding an unbroken lineage of specific Daniels across three millennia is impossible. Instead, I want to learn if the name was in the â€œcultural consciousnessâ€. If so, we can be modestly confident that real people are getting named Daniel, like how real people are being named Khaleesi today. So letâ€™s start with where the name was first found. Ugarit was a port city of the shores of Ras Shamra, unknown until 1928. Scholars believe that it was a city of roughly 8,000 people and the capitol of a kingdom of 20,000 (ref). While never a great power, Ugarit was a fairly â€œliterateâ€ society and had extensive trade relations with all of the regional powers. Along with a trove of archaeological material (pots and doodads), excavators also found large collections of clay tablets. Like with many Bronze Age civilizations, most of these recovered documents are either religious, diplomatic, or administrative. Thatâ€™s because clay tablets are expensive and only reserved for important matters. Most of these were dated to very approximately 1500-1200 BCE. But also in that collection, we found three piece of literature. The first, the Baal Cycle, tells of how Baal Hadad became one of the great gods of the Ugaritic pantheon. The second, the Legend of Keret, probably matters a lot to another person chasing a completely different white whale, but doesnâ€™t matter to me. The final one, the one that started this obsession of mine, is the Tale of Aqhat. One of three recovered tablets that make up the tale. (source) I found this picture in the InscriptiFact collection. Sadly no digital transcription! It tells of the story of the great hero Aqhat, who was loved and murdered by the goddess Anath. But I donâ€™t actually care about any of that, Iâ€™m only after the Daniel. Iâ€™m pretty sure this is Danielâ€™s name: I have a few friends who can read cuneiform, so I asked if any understood this text. I found out 1) thatâ€™s like asking a person who â€œcan read ASCIIâ€ if they can understand Spanish, and 2) this is not actually cuneiform. Itâ€™s just an alphabet that looks like cuneiform. The Ugaritic alphabet. (source) Aqhatâ€™s father is ðŽ„ðŽðŽ›ðŽ. Left to right: D, N, â€˜I, L. â€œJudged by Elâ€, El being the chief God in the Ugaritic pantheon. The name could be older than this text, since most early written myths were first oral traditions. This is just the first time the name â€œDanielâ€ is attested. The name could also be a lot younger, at least the modern name. The old name could just be an unusual coincidence, like how people in both England and China have the last name â€œLeeâ€.2 For â€œDanielâ€ to be that old, itâ€™s not enough for the Ugarits to have had the name, it has to come from them, in a chain of Daniels reaching into present. And here we run into a problem. We know roughly how old the tablets are because we know roughly when the city collapsed. By cross-referencing names of Egyptian rulers that appear in Ugarit tablets with the much better preserved Egyptian corpus, historians estimate that the city collapsed around 1190 BCE. This corresponds with the â€œBronze Age Collapseâ€, a cataclysmic era where dozens of cities and kingdoms in the region are turned to ruins. Scholars still donâ€™t have a clear picture why. Regardless of the why, the Ugarites disappeared from history. The name Daniel would have to be carried by a new generation. But this is also where the chain breaks. Phoenicia The Ras Shamra find was a one-in-a-million miracle, an enormous corpus of about 40,000 words, roughly as much as one Harlequin romance novel. After that? Well, hereâ€™s the Hadad Statue: The Hadad Statue (source) If you look closely, you can see the bottom is covered in faint writing. The language is â€œSamalianâ€, one of the many languages in the region. The engraving is roughly 400 words long and represents over half of all Samalian. This essay is four times longer than the Samalian corpus. So what happened? Itâ€™s easy to imagine the Bronze Age Collapse turning the broader region into a Stone Age wasteland, but the archaeological evidence suggests the opposite. Rather, it points to a rapid economic recovery of the region, with new kingdoms soon establishing a large number of seafaring trade routes. Eventually theyâ€™d come in contact with the Greeks, whoâ€™d call all of the many distinct groups â€œPhoeniciansâ€. But we know so little of what the â€œPhoeniciansâ€ (in all their languages) wrote because of how they wrote it. Instead of Ugaritâ€™s clay tablets, the Phoenicians used papyrus. Papyrus is lighter and cheaper, but also rots after a few decades. The fragments of text we do haveâ€” with one big exceptionâ€” are engravings.3 Inscriptions on tombs, statues, weapons, etc. This is a major problem for historians, but an even bigger problem for me, because it makes the question of Daniel impossible to answer. Nonetheless, we can look for clues that the same stories persisted, even if we donâ€™t have concrete evidence. Letâ€™s start with the first two lines of the Hadad statue: ð¤€ð¤ð¤Š ð¤ð¤ð¤Œð¤… Â· ð¤ð¤“ Â· ð¤’ð¤“ð¤‹ Â· ð¤Œð¤‹ð¤Š Â· ð¤‰ð¤€ð¤ƒð¤‰ Â· ð¤†ð¤‰ Â· ð¤„ð¤’ð¤Œð¤• Â· ð¤ð¤‘ð¤ Â· ð¤†ð¤ Â· ð¤‹ð¤„ð¤ƒð¤ƒ Â· ð¤ð¤ð¤‹ð¤Œð¤‰Â· ð¤’ð¤Œð¤… Â· ð¤ð¤Œð¤‰Ì‡ Â·Â· ð¤€Ì‡ð¤‹ð¤„ð¤… Â·Â· ð¤„ð¤ƒð¤ƒ Â· ð¤…ð¤€ð¤‹ Â· ð¤…ð¤“ð¤”ð¤ Â· ð¤…ð¤“ð¤Šð¤ð¤€ð¤‹ Â· ð¤…ð¤”ð¤Œð¤” Â· ð¤…ð¤ð¤•ð¤ Â· ð¤ð¤‰ð¤ƒð¤‰ This is the â€œPhoenician alphabetâ€â€”the same one that inspired the Greek alphabetâ€” which many distinct cultures in the region used for their own languages. Unlike Ugaritic, itâ€™s read right-to-left. Scholars donâ€™t think this alphabet descended from Ugaritic, but the two writing systems are closely related: the same sounds appear in roughly the same places in the alphabet.4 Hereâ€™s the translation (from wiki): I am Panamuwa, son of Qarli, king of Yâ€™DY, who have erected this statue for Hadad in my eternal abode (burial chamber). The gods Hadad and El and RaÅ¡ap and RÄkib-El and Å amaÅ¡ supported me. The same gods, El and Baal Hadad, are important gods in the Ugarit corpus! And this is coming four hundred years after the fall of Ugarit. It suggests the Baal Hadad and El werenâ€™t local gods to the Ugarits, but regional gods, part of a shared culture. The tale of Aqhat could have been preserved as a literary tradition, just on sources we donâ€™t have anymore. And with Aqhat comes his dad(niel). To get out of the Daniel dark ages, we have to look at a different inscription found 600 miles away. The Misha Stele (source) Like the Hadad statue, the Misha Stele is one of our only sources on a long-dead language. In this case, Moabite. Itâ€™s a distinct language from Samalian but this uses the same Phoenician alphabet. Hereâ€™s a sample (also from wiki): I have built its gates and I have built its towers. I have built the palace of the king, and I made the prisons for the criminals within the wall. And there were no wells in the interior of the wall in Karchah. And I said to all the people, â€˜Make you every man a well in his house.â€™ And I dug the ditch for Karchah with the chosen men of Israel. Israel? Yes, Israel. The Greeks called this region Phoenicia, but the locals always called it Canaan. The same â€œCanaanâ€ from the Bible. The Israelites were a Canaanite population with Canaanite religions: Israel literally means One who fought El. Slowly, over years and centuries, they developed their own ethnic identity. At some point, there were two Israelite kingdoms: the kingdom of Israel/Samaria in the north and the kingdom of Judah (where we get â€œJewâ€) in the south. Moab is here, too (source) Israel was conquered in 720 BCE while the kingdom of Judah limps along, in one form or another, until 130 CE.5 And itâ€™s through the people of Judah that we have the best corpus of that regionâ€™s writing. "PrÃ©sentation de la Loi" (source) The Torah, or â€œOld Testamentâ€, is a 300,000 word corpus of ancient Hebrew, chronicling the stories, religious practices, and history (mythic and attested) of the Jews.6 Itâ€™s the reason we can decipher the scant inscriptions of other Canaanite languages like Moabite, Samalian, and even Ugaritic itself! And itâ€™s where the tale of Daniel continues. Judah Quick recap on Daniel so far: we know the Ugarites wrote about a son of Daniel, the Canaanites (nee Phoenicians) shared a culture with the Ugarites, and the Israelites shared a culture with the Canaanites. In 600 BCE, the Neo-Babylonian empire conquered Judah, which leads to the sixty year â€œBabylonian exileâ€ of Jews from Canaan. Itâ€™s allegedly during this time that we get the collection of prophecies known as the â€œBook of Ezekielâ€.7 Mostly itâ€™s about how the Jews lost the favor of God and will one day earn it back, and with it redemption. Far, far more importantly, it marks the triumphant return of Daniel. â€œSon of man, if a land sins against Me by trespassing grievously, I shall stretch forth My hand upon it and break its staff of bread, and I shall send famine upon it and cut off from it both man and beast. Now should these three men be in its midst- Noah, Daniel, and Job-they would save themselves with their righteousness, says the Lord God.8 â€” Ezekiel 14:13-14 Daniel is written (×“× ××œ). As a distant descendent of Phoenician, Hebrew reads right-to-left: Daled, Nun, Aleph, Lamed. â€œGod judged me.â€ Same meaning as the Ugaritic name, same letters as ðŽ„ðŽðŽ›ðŽ. Iâ€™m amazed that the same meaning can be preserved across so many centuries. But I also want to be as thorough as possible. Two names, eight hundred years apart, with the same meaning, is still not enough for me. I still worry that it could just be an enormous coincidence that two cultures in the same region, speaking sister languages, came up with the same name-meaning. Ezekiel provides the missing link. In the Torah, both Noah and Job are treated as pious men, but critically, neither are Israelites.9 Making Daniel part of the trio implies he was also a righteous non-Jew. Ezekiel would expect people would know who â€œDanielâ€ was if he used that name. This would make sense if Daniel was, say, a righteous figure in the broader Canaanite folklore. At least the Tale of Aqhat implies he was a righteous and just man who was worthy of Elâ€™s blessing. He prayed for a son and his wish was granted. Heâ€™d be a distinct character, a known righteous non-Israelite, which Ezekiel used as a point of reference. A tenuous chain, I know, but enough to persuade me at least. Enough to persuade other scholars too. It may be the best weâ€™ll ever do. We can finally use the Bible to establish that Daniel wasnâ€™t just a folkloric name, but a name people actually used. From the Book of Ezra: And these are the heads of their fatherâ€™s houses and the lineage of those who ascended with me in the kingdom of King Artaxerxes from Babylon. Of the sons of Phinehas, Gershom: of the sons of Ithamar, Daniel; of the sons of David, Hattush. â€” Ezra 8:1-2 And these were the sons of David who were born to him in Hebron: the firstborn, Amnon, to Ahinoam the Jezreelitess; the second, Daniel, to Abigail the Carmelitess. â€” Chronicles 3:1 If theyâ€™re using Daniel as the name of a minor son of a minor figure, itâ€™s probably a real name. The False Daniel But now we have a problem. The Ezekiel Daniel has four letters. But all of the later Daniels have five: Daled, Nun, Yud, Aleph, Lamed (×“× ×™××œ) . Itâ€™s still possible to read the four-letter version as â€œDanielâ€ but itâ€™s more likely to be â€œDanelâ€ or â€œDanilâ€. And, Ezekielâ€™s Daniel being closest to the Ugaritic DNâ€™IL, suggests that DNâ€™IL was also â€œDanelâ€. Thatâ€™s how most modern scholars now transliterate the name. So yes, I may have been chasing a false Daniel this whole time. Theophanu is not Tiffany, after all. Maybe â€œDanielâ€ is at best attested from 600 BCE, putting it in contention with things like Debrah and Zhou. There is a tradition to pronounce the Ezekiel DNâ€™IL as â€œDanielâ€, so it could be the actual pronunciation and the Yud was added later. I donâ€™t know when the tradition started, though. At the very least, this strengthens the connection between Ezekielâ€™s ×“× ××œ and the Ugariteâ€™s ðŽ„ðŽðŽ›ðŽ: Ezekiel was working off a different name than the rest of the Torah authors. Then again, maybe this is all just quibbling over specifics. The Latin alphabet wasnâ€™t meant for Canaanite names, and the Hebrew alphabet wasnâ€™t meant for Ugaritic ones. The Biblical ×©×¨×” could be Romanized as â€œSarahâ€ or â€œSaraâ€, ×—× ×›×” could be Hannukah, Channuka, or Chanukah. Maybe it doesnâ€™t matter whether ðŽ„ðŽðŽ›ðŽ is ×“× ×™××œ or Danel or ×“× ××œ or Daniel. Itâ€™s still the same name. Regardless, weâ€™re following a chain, and thereâ€™s still one more link. From Daniel to Today Thereâ€™s one last question here: lots of people use Torah names, like Sarah and Benjamin and David. But many Torah names, like Tamar and Yehuda and Hillel, are only used by Jews. Why is Daniel in the former group and not the latter? Iâ€™d speculate that the difference is how likely it is for a Christian reader to encounter the name. â€œAdamâ€ appears in the first book of Genesis, while Shamgar is a minor figure in the book of Judges. Christians would most likely encounter names that appear either really early, have entertaining stories, or are directly relevant to the New Testament. And hereâ€™s where we finally get to the last link between then and now: the Book of Daniel. Like the Book of Ezekiel, this recounts the story of someone living during the Babylonian exile. Unlike Ezekiel, it was pretty clearly written four hundred years after the exile. Daniel contains an awful lot of prophecies that seem very relevant to the Greek occupation (the one that leads to the story of Channukah). The most famous of them is the prophecy of 70 weeks: And you shall know and understand that from the emergence of the word to restore and to rebuild Jerusalem until the anointed king [shall be] seven weeks, and [for] sixty-two weeks it will return and be built street and moat, but in troubled times. â€” Daniel 9:25 Later writers took this to be a prophecy about Jesus. I donâ€™t admit to understand how itâ€™s supposed to be about Jesus, but it is. So the book of Daniel is really important in Christian thought. This kept the name â€œDanielâ€ in the Christian mainstream for the next 2000 years, carrying it across the world to Europe and India and East Asia and South America, all the way to the present daytoday. The end of a 3400 year chain. So thatâ€™s the story of the name of Daniel, from an ancient clay tablet to the millions of Daniels alive now. I want to reiterate that Iâ€™m not a trained historian and almost certainly got a lot of details wrong. Also, this isnâ€™t and wouldnâ€™t pass peer review. Donâ€™t cite this for a class paper. Happy April Cools! Thanks to Predrag Gruevski for feedback. If you enjoyed this, check out the April Cools website for all the other pieces this year! I accessed JSTOR as a UChicago Alumnus benefit, but I also found out that anyone with a Chicago public library card has access too! Hundreds of public libraries do this! [return] Note though that the Chinese â€œLeeâ€ is just one possible Romanization of æŽ. â€œLiâ€ is another. [return] We have a much larger Egyptian corpus because papyrus lasts longer in Egyptâ€™s hot and arid climate. We have large Greek and Roman corpuses because monks tirelessly copied old texts into new books for centuries. Volcanoes helped. [return] We know the order because weâ€™ve recovered Ugarit abedecaries (inscriptions of all an alphabetâ€™s letters in order). [return] At least, thatâ€™s when Jews were permanently expelled from the region. Growing up I was taught that the important event was the burning of the Second Temple, which happened in 70 CE. [return] I grew up an Orthodox Jew, and itâ€™s extremely weird to study the actual history of your religion. Like vivisecting holy books. [return] From my research it seems that itâ€™s generally accepted that most of Ezekiel is written contemporaneously with the Babylonian exile, though it may have been smoothed out later. [return] For Old Testament verses Iâ€™m using the Chabad translations. My Hebrew never got past a first grade level. [return] Noah is obvious: his story takes place before Abrahamâ€™s. Job is tougher, as thereâ€™s nothing in the story that makes it clear heâ€™s not Jewish. Iâ€™m basing this off the claims of many different Rabbis and modern scholars. originBody: SMART NEWS Cool Finds These Century-Old Stone â€œTsunami Stonesâ€ Dot Japanâ€™s Coastline â€œRemember the calamity of the great tsunamis. Do not build any homes below this point.â€ Danny Lewis August 31, 2015 T.KISHIMOTO, via Wikimedia Commons. At the edge of Aneyoshi, a small village on Japanâ€™s northeastern coast, a 10-foot-tall stone tablet stands, carved with a dire warning to locals. "High dwellings are the peace and harmony of our descendants," the rock slab says. "Remember the calamity of the great tsunamis. Do not build any homes below this point." While the Aneyoshi tablet might be the most straightforward, so-called â€œtsunami stonesâ€ dot Japanâ€™s coastline, warning the carversâ€™ descendants to seek high ground after earthquakes in case they foreshadow destructive waves. The stones vary in degrees of repair, with most dating back to around 1896, when two deadly tsunamis killed about 22,000 people, Martin Fackler writes for The New York Times. â€œThe tsunami stones are warnings across generations, telling descendants to avoid the same suffering of their ancestors,â€ Itoko Kitahara, a historian of natural disasters at Ritsumeikan University in Kyoto, told Fackler in 2011 after an earthquake killed nearly 29,000 people. â€œSome places heeded these lessons of the past, but many didnâ€™t,â€ Kitahara told Fackler. Over the decades, the stonesâ€™ warnings were disregarded or forgotten by many as coastal towns boomed and people placed their faith in massive seawalls built by the Japanese government. The article highlights the significance of transmitting the memories of past disasters, especially after the 2011 tsunami in Japan, to upcoming generations.
